title: 107_s1196
content: The "Small Business Investment Company Amendments Act of 2001" amends subsidy fees under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958, increasing the maximum fee to 1.38 percent per year. The effective date for these amendments is October 1, 2001. Additionally, conflicts of interest provisions are revised by removing the requirement for disclosure in the locality most directly affected by the transaction. SEC. 4. PENALTIES FOR FALSE STATEMENTS. Amends criminal and civil penalties related to false statements in connection with small business investment companies and the Small Business Administration. SEC. 5. REMOVAL OR SUSPENSION OF MANAGEMENT OFFICIALS. Amends the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 to define 'management official' and outline the process for removal based on willful violations. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 defines a 'management official' and outlines the process for their removal based on willful violations of fiduciary duties involving personal dishonesty. The notice of intention to remove a management official must state the grounds for removal and schedule a hearing within 30 to 60 days. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 allows for the removal of a management official if they do not appear at a hearing or consent to removal. The Administrator can issue orders of removal if grounds for removal are established, which become effective after 30 days of service. The Administrator has the authority to suspend or prohibit a management official from participating in the affairs of a licensee if deemed necessary for protection. The suspension or prohibition becomes effective upon notice and remains in effect unless stayed by a court. The Administrator can suspend or prohibit a management official from a licensee pending administrative proceedings. The management official can seek judicial review for a stay of the suspension or prohibition. The Administrator has the authority to suspend or prohibit a management official from a licensee if charged with a felony involving dishonesty or breach of trust. The suspension or prohibition remains in effect until the case is resolved, or until terminated by the Administrator. If convicted, the suspension continues until the judgment is final. The Administrator can remove a management official upon serving an order, even if found not guilty, and must notify the licensee. Procedural provisions and judicial review are also outlined. After a hearing, the Administrator must render a decision within 90 days and issue orders consistent with the provisions of the section. The Administrator has the authority to modify, terminate, or set aside any order issued under this section at any time unless a petition for review is filed in a court of appeals. Judicial review of orders issued under this section can be obtained by filing a petition in a court of appeals within 30 days. The curr_chunk discusses the process of filing a petition to modify, terminate, or set aside an order of the Administrator. The court has exclusive jurisdiction to review and make a final judgment on the Administrator's order. The court follows procedures outlined in title 5, United States Code for the review process. The final judgment and decree are subject to review by the Supreme Court of the United States upon certiorari. Proceedings for judicial review do not automatically stay any order issued by the Administrator under this section. SEC. 6. REDUCTION OF FEES. Two-Year Reduction of Section 7(a) Fees: Guarantee fees for loans approved during a 2-year period starting October 1, 2002, will have reduced rates based on the loan amount. Annual fees for loans approved during the same period will also be adjusted. During a 2-year period starting October 1, 2002, guarantee fees and annual fees for loans under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 will be reduced. The guarantee fee may not exceed 50 percent of the established amount for loans made during this period, and no up front guarantee fee will be assessed or collected for loans made under this title during the same 2-year period. During the 2-year period starting on October 1, 2002, loans and financings made by the Small Business Administration will be treated as separate programs for budgetary purposes. The amendments to the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 will only be effective if funds are available to offset the costs. These changes will take effect on October 1, 2002.
